joined the Defending Social Security Caucus newly organized by fellow Democratic Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont. "Social Security has not contributed a dime to the debt or the deficit," he said, calling the program rock-solid for at least another 27 years. That was a reference to the moment when Social Security's trustees project that the system's trust fund-- financed by payroll taxes that are segregated from other federal levies-- will run out.
